title: 105_hr639
content:
The Commission on Structural Alternatives for the Federal Courts of Appeals is established to study and make recommendations on the division and structure of the United States judicial circuits, with a focus on the Ninth Circuit. The Commission will report its findings to the President and Congress for consideration of changes in circuit boundaries or structure to improve the efficiency of the Federal Courts of Appeals. The Commission on Structural Alternatives for the Federal Courts of Appeals is composed of 8 members appointed by various officials. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission elects a Chair and Vice Chair from its members. A quorum consists of four members, but hearings can be conducted with three members. Compensation details are not provided. SEC. 3. COMPENSATION.

Members of the Commission who are Federal officers or employees shall receive no additional compensation for their services but shall be reimbursed for travel and other necessary expenses. Non-Federal members will receive $200 per day for duties performed plus expenses reimbursement. The Commission may appoint an Executive Director who will receive compensation not exceeding the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Executive Director can appoint additional personnel without following certain regulations, and their compensation should not exceed the maximum rate for a position above GS-15. The Executive Director of the Commission may hire experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the highest level under the General Schedule pay rates. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts will provide administrative services on a reimbursable basis, while the Federal Judicial Center will provide research services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission is authorized to request information and assistance from government entities to carry out its functions. A report must be submitted within 1 year of the enactment of the Act, with the Commission terminating 90 days after. $500,000 is authorized for appropriations to the Commission.
